title: IDFC to start operation on October 1 with 23 branches: Rajiv Lall
text: MUMBAI: Even as the stock market was down 250 points, shares of IDFC rose 4 per cent in intraday trading after the company disclosed to the Bombay Stock Exchange that it has been granted banking licence from the Reserve Bank of India. The term lending financial institution will be christened as IDFC Bank and is expected start operations from October 1 of this year with 23 branches across India. The shares of IDFC closed at Rs 157 on Friday, up 2.5 per cent over Thursday. IDFC and micro-finance company Bandhan were the only two entities among 20 odd aspirants that received banking licences. The company has posted a profit of Rs 1,707 crore for fiscal year 2014-15, down 5 per cent from Rs 1,824 crore a year ago. Speaking to ET, Rajiv Lall , executive chairman of IDFC said, "We will start with 23 branches and increase it to 50 over the next six to eight months." It will open 15 branches in Madhya Pradesh and 1 branch each in Mumbai, Delhi, Ahmedabad, Hyderabad, Kolkata , Chennai and Bangalore. "Initially, retail operations for 15 branches in MP while corporate banking in other cities will go live from October 1. Over the next few week, retail operation will go live in other cities." As of now, IDFC has 5 offices across India. He indicated that the company has hired 500-600 people over the last few months. IDFC, which will have its AGM on July 30, has sought shareholders' approval to raise Rs 80,000 crore in form of non- convertible bonds and certificate of deposits. It has a loan book of Rs 54,745 crore, total borrowings of Rs 66,252 crore and a balance sheet size of Rs 87,068 crore. Government owns majority stake of 16.4 per cent followed by 9.5 per cent Sipadan Investments, an arm of Khazanah Nasional Bhd. IDFC was founded in 1997 following an announcement made in union budget wherein former finance minister P Chidambaram said that IDFC would "act as a direct lender, as a refinancing institution and as a provider of financial guarantees," and "to make available long-term funds at the lowest possible market rates."
